courses.name: Bilingualism, Multilingualism, and Second Language Acquisition

cmCourseInfo.description: Knowing and speaking more than one language is the everyday norm of people living in much of the world including in multicultural cities like Toronto. Via an in-depth introduction to the cognitive and social underpinnings of bi- and multilingualism including second language acquisition, this course provides answers to questions such as How do bilinguals/multilinguals differ from monolinguals in the ways that they process and use language? How does acquiring a language as an adult differ from when we are children? How do an individual’s language repertoires interact with those of their peers and local community?
cmCourseInfo.title: Bilingualism, Multilingualism, and Second Language Acquisition
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4.0 FCE, including 1.0 FCE in language or linguistics courses (e.g. LIN200H1, FRE272H1, ITA360H1, SLA323H1/SLA380H1, SPA322H1).

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is a 3-hour course (R2-5). All students must register in both the main lecture (R2-4) as well as one of the tutorials below (R4-5). A portion of the final grade will be determined uniquely by students' participation in the tutorial. TUT0101 (FRENCH): This tutorial will be conducted in French. Students enrolled in a Major or Specialist program in French must enroll in the French tutorial. TUT0201 (GERMAN): This tutorial will be conducted in German. German specialists, majors, and minors choosing this elective course must enroll in the German-language tutorial. TUT0301 (ENGLISH): This tutorial will be conducted in English and is open to students from departments other than French Studies or Germanic Languages & Literatures.
